metadata.chief_complaint: newborn check, detailed family history including maternal depression

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi Mom, congratulations! Let me see this handsome boy. How's everyone doing at home?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Thank you. We're... surviving. It's been harder than I expected honestly.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's completely normal to feel that way. The first few weeks are intense. Tell me about how Lucas is eating.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: I'm breastfeeding, or trying to. It's been really hard. He wants to eat constantly but I don't know if he's getting enough.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: How often is he nursing?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Every one to two hours during the day. A little longer at night, maybe three hour stretches.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: And how many wet and dirty diapers?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Wet, probably six to eight a day. Poops are yellow now, usually three or four a day.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's actually really reassuring. Those are exactly the numbers we want to see. Let me check his weight.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: He's eight pounds two ounces. What was his birth weight and discharge weight?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: He was seven pounds eight ounces at birth, and seven four when we left the hospital.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: So he's gained ten ounces above his discharge weight. That's excellent. He's gaining beautifully on breast milk alone.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Really? I was so worried I wasn't making enough.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: His weight tells us he's getting plenty. You're doing a great job.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I want to ask about family history. Any health conditions on either side of the family I should know about?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Let me think. My mom has diabetes, type 2. My dad had a heart attack in his sixties. Um, my husband's dad has high cholesterol.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Any childhood illnesses or developmental concerns in the family?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: No, I don't think so. Everyone was healthy as kids.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Any history of depression or anxiety in the family?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Um, yes actually. I had depression in college, before I met my husband. And my sister has anxiety. Why do you ask?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I ask everyone, but especially because having a history of depression is a risk factor for postpartum depression. How are you feeling emotionally?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Honestly? Not great. I cry a lot. I feel like I don't know what I'm doing. Sometimes I just feel so overwhelmed I want to run away.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Thank you for being honest with me. What you're describing is really common, and it sounds like more than just the baby blues. Have you had any thoughts of hurting yourself or the baby?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: No, nothing like that. I love him so much. I just feel like I'm failing at this.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: You are absolutely not failing. What you're describing sounds like postpartum depression, and it's treatable. It doesn't mean you're a bad mom. It means you need some support.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: I didn't want to say anything because I felt ashamed.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: There's no shame in this. Your brain chemistry is going through huge shifts right now. Would you be open to talking to someone about how you're feeling?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Yes. I think I need to.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Good. I'm going to give you a referral to a therapist who specializes in perinatal mental health. And I want you to follow up with your OB this week to talk about whether medication might help. Are you okay with that?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Yes. My husband has been worried about me too. He'll be relieved I'm getting help.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'm glad you have support at home. Let's examine Lucas now.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: He looks great. Good tone, good color. Fontanelle is soft and flat. Heart sounds normal. Hips are stable. Umbilical stump is clean and dry.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: He's a healthy two week old. No concerns from my exam. He doesn't need any vaccines today, we'll start those at two months.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: When do I bring him back?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'd like to see him at one month, and I want to check in on how you're doing too. Call me if anything comes up before then, with him or with you.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Thank you. For everything. For asking about me.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Of course. Taking care of you is part of taking care of him.
